project.teaser: The WeForming project aims to change the paradigm of efficiently managing energy in buildings, paying special attention to their interaction with the energy ecosystem (energy networks and markets) by developing, deploying and demonstrating innovative solutions addressing (i)...
project.objective: The WeForming project aims to change the paradigm of efficiently managing energy in buildings, paying special attention to their interaction with the energy ecosystem (energy networks and markets) by developing, deploying and demonstrating innovative solutions addressing (i) digital operation, management and maintenance and (ii) efficient and interactive energy processing for Intelligent Grid-interactive Efficient Buildings (iGEBs), able to operate intelligently in a multi-energy, multi-user, multi-sector, multi-market, and multi-objective environment, without forgetting quality, comfort, health and acceptation. The WeForming Framework will deploy an umbrella framework covering all aspects around the establishment and adoption of iGEBs in cities, which consists of (i) a Building Operational Pillar encompassing all assets of iGEBs, including the energy management systems and the different platforms, aiming towards the building operational optimization, the actors and the actual flexibility resources, generation and storage components; (ii) a novel Interoperability Assurance Pillar which leverages on, adapts, evolves, and specifically validates leading-edge interoperable architectures; (iii) a Business Pillar including all necessary processes to bring the proposed solutions to the market, through the design and validation of sustainable and competitive business models, ensuring the economic viability of the investments needed for the establishment of smart cities featuring new and refurbished iGEBs; (iv) a Smart-city enabling Pillar integrating iGEBs as modular units addressing all different non-technical barriers and limitations for the widespread deployment of the proposed solutions that will create a stock of active buildings acting as active utility nodes within cities.
project.title: Buildings as Efficient Interoperable Formers of Clean Energy Ecosystems
project.keywords: intelligent buildings, building-to-grid integration, data space connector, SGAM architectures, power hub

article.title: Energy management for sustainable urban living

category.title: Project description
category.description: Article: description of linked project written by editorial team

result.title: WeForming Services Co-Creation, Business Models, Functional Specifications and Reference Architecture (2nd version)
result.description: This deliverable will provide an update of Deliverable 2.2. It will deal with the user engagement awareness and co-creation. It will include a detailed description of the business models that the project will develop for building to grid integration. It will detail the functional specifications for interoperability and standardized data integration between iGFBs and their energy eco-system. Finally, this deliverable will include a second description of the W-IBRA reference architecture. Success Criteria: Definition of services and design of the Architecture. Tasks (2.4, 2.5, 2.6, 2.7). This will be the second version of this deliverable.

result.title: Communication and dissemination plan and branding
result.description: Communication and dissemination planThis deliverable will define and present in detail the plan for the dissemination and communication activities of the whole WeForming project. Success criteria: Availability of a concrete plan with specific milestones and KPIs. Task 7.1.

result.title: SOTA analysis, barriers, regulatory framework and end-users’ requirements
result.description: This deliverable will include an extensive analysis of the state of the art in the energy storage solutions domain. It will make an elaborate presentation of the barriers that hinder the wide-spread deployment of the different forms of storage. Within this deliverable the regulatory framework surrounding Energy storage will be reviewed and assessed and finally the document will include a detailed presentation of the use-cases coming partially from the project pilots. Success Criteria: The definition of the use-cases. (Task 2.1, Task 2.2, Task 2.3).

result.title: Virtual Energy Storage Stacking in Day-Ahead and mFRR markets - A Spanish Case Study

details.authors: Ángel Paredes, José A. Aguado, Pedro Rodríguez
details.journalTitle: 2024 IEEE 15th International Symposium on Power Electronics for Distributed Generation Systems (PEDG)

details.journalTitle: 2024 IEEE 15th International Symposium on Power Electronics for Distributed Generation Systems (PEDG)

result.title: On the participation of energy storage systems in reserve markets using Decision Focused Learning

details.authors: Ángel Paredes, Jean-François Toubeau, José A. Aguado, François Vallée

result.title: Sustainable Energy, Grids and Networks

details.authors: Tomislav Antić, Andrew Keane, Tomislav Capuder

result.title: Data Management Plan
result.description: This Deliverable will summarize the Data management and IPR protection procedures that will be followed during the course of the project. It will provide the analysis of the Data management policy and the Data management lifecycle for the datasets that will be collected, processed or generated by the project. Success Criteria: The availability of the report. (Task 1.4).

result.title: Forecasting and Optimization as a Service for Energy Management Applications with the Energy Service Generics Framework
WeForming Services Co-Creation, Business Models, Functional Specifications and Reference Architecture (1st version)
result.description: This deliverable will deal with the user engagement awareness and co-creation. It will include a detailed description of the business models that the project will develop for building to grid integration. It will detail the functional specifications for interoperability and standardized data integration between iGFBs and their energy eco-system. Finally, this deliverable will include a first description of the W-IBRA reference architecture. Success Criteria: Definition of services and design of the Architecture. Tasks (2.4, 2.5, 2.6, 2.7). This will be the first version of this deliverable.

result.title: WeForming demos’ execution documentation (pre-demo operations)
result.description: This deliverable will document all details surrounding the operation of the project pilots during the pre-demo phase and will provide all the necessary documentation.General and technical details about the demo deployment, the on-site details, the scenarios, the integration and the initial operation will be documented. Early results will be identified.Success Criteria: Availability of the report in terms of the pre-pilot scope. (Tasks 5.2, 5.3, 5.4, 5.5, 5.6, 5.7).

result.title: Power-Dependent Price Profiles - Defining Grid- and Market-Oriented Incentives for Building Energy Management Systems

details.authors: Tobias Riedel, Carl Hauschke, Hartmut Schmeck

result.title: Hosting capacity in the Croatian regulatory environment
Learning a reward function for user-preferred appliance scheduling

details.authors: Nikolina Čović, Jochen L. Cremer, Hrvoje Pandžić

result.title: Modelling And Simulation Of A Carnot Battery Coupled To Seasonal Underground Stratified Thermal Energy Storage For Heating, Cooling And Electricity Generation

details.authors: Aitor Cendoya, Frederic Ransy, Vincent Lemort, Andres Hernandez, Pierre Dewallef, Pierre-Henri Gresse and Jacques Windeshausen

result.title: WeForming software building blocks and technological enablers (digital platforms, digital twins, BIM/SRI models, AI/ML tools) (1st technology release)
result.description: This Deliverable will include the first version of the WeForming Software Building blocks and Technological enablers and will deal with their specification, design and development. It will include the proprietary digital platforms and tools that already exist in the pilots and deal with their extension to fit to the WeFroming Framework. It will also design digital and data models for the digital twins and BIMs and finally the AI/ML tools for iGFBs. This will be the first version of this deliverable. Success Criteria: Operational versions of all software technological enablers of W-IBRA (partial functionality - 1st Release)Tasks: 3.1, 3.4, 3.5

result.title: Communication, dissemination, exploitation and market exploration, standardisation and community building (1st progress report and plan)
result.description: This document will report the dissemination, communication and exploitation activities performed during the first 18 months, the results achieved and an updated version of the respective plans. Standardisation activities will be documented and the enterpreneureal engagement weill be discussed in terms of concrete activities. Finally, the clustering activities with other projects and Initiatives of the EC will be documented. Success Criteria: The document should report the achieved results and the new/updated plans.(Tasks 7.1, 7.2, 7.3, 7.4, 7.5)

result.title: WeForming hardware building blocks and technological enablers (real-time controller, processing hubs) (1st technology release)
result.description: This Deliverable will include the first version of the WeForming Hardware Building blocks and Technological enablers and will deal with their specification, design and development. It will include the real-time controller which will coordinate the multi-energy asset operation of iGFB components. Moreover, this deliverable will include the design and development of the processing hubs for the flexible interaction of iGFBs with the distribution network. This will be the first version of this deliverable. Success Criteria: Operational versions of all hardware technological enablers of W-IBRA (partial functionality - 1st Release)Tasks: 3.2, 3.3.

result.title: WeForming integrated platform (catalogue of services, data space connector, middleware, integrated solution) (1st technology release)
result.description: This Delivarable will include the first description of the interoperability enablers of the WeForming Framework. It will detail the catalogue of services, the data space connector, the WeForming middleware and the whole integrated system as well as the security, privacy and data sovereignty considerations. This will be the first version of this deliverable. Success Criteria: Operational versions of all interoperability technological enablers and successful integration into the W-IBRA digital platform (partial functionality - 1st Release)Tasks 4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.4, 4.5.

result.title: The role of demand-side flexibility in harmonics-considered dynamic hosting capacity

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
